of Arts, Design and Architecture","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOMA1001 - Media Arts Gateway 1","description":"

SOMA1001 Media Arts Gateway 1 is an introductory course for students in the Bachelor of Media Arts. It explores the nature of sound and vision by capturing and manipulating audio and still images, before progressing to images in motion and the sequencing of audio-visual time. Working with sound in the digital realm, students will use audio recorders to study and test the technical implications of timbre, frequency, acoustics and context. When transferring images to monitor and paper students will use the still camera to study light, colour, framing and composition. 

This will assist students in selecting studio areas for further study. SOMA1001 and SOMA1002 courses are complementary and may be completed in any order.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9044c814dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961904","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 3: Sound/Image project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

The purpose of this assessment is to apply principles of sound and photography in a limited audiovisual project. Students will create an individual sound /image project that expands upon the apparent meanings conveyed by your sound projects\ in Assessment Task 1. This will be a video/animation piece of between 30 seconds to one minute.

Feedback given in class provides a benchmark for what will be expected in future digital photography coursework and provide peer assessment opportunities. Reviewing the work and immediately explaining what is successful and how to improve gives the student the opportunity for questions and discussion.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1c44c814dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961905","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1044c814dbb1fc90be4672f5f396190b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: Photographic Portrait (memento mori)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The purpose of this assessment is to apply principles of photography to a photographic portrait without taking a literal interpretation of the subject matter. Students will research a portrait subject and consider how the subject and their stories can told within the confines of the frame. The project requires a single image that tells the story of the subject. 

Feedback given in class provides a benchmark for what will be expected in future digital photography coursework and provide peer assessment opportunities. Reviewing the work and immediately explaining what is successful and how to improve gives the student the opportunity for questions and discussion.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1444c814dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961905","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1844c814dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961908","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1: Sound Diary and Sound Portrait","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

The purpose of this assessment is to develop listening skills in order to identify, deconstruct and reconstruct sound. This assessment is split into two parts: The Sound Diary and the Sound Portrait.

  • The Sound Diary is an individual assessment and is comprised of a written work based on your observations of sounds within your environment(s).
  • The Sound Portrait is a group assessment and is comprised of a digitally manipulated audio landscape that includes elements of the Sound Diary.

Feedback given in class provides a benchmark for what will be expected in future sound production coursework and provide peer assessment opportunities. Reviewing the work and immediately explaining what is successful and how to improve gives the student the opportunity for questions and discussion.

SOMA1001 Media Arts Gateway 1 is an introductory course for students in the Bachelor of Media Arts. It explores the nature of sound and vision by capturing and manipulating audio and still images, before progressing to images in motion and the sequencing of audio-visual time. Working with sound in the digital realm, students will use audio recorders to study and test the technical implications of timbre, frequency, acoustics and context. When transferring images to monitor and paper students will use the still camera to study light, colour, framing and composition. 

This will assist students in selecting studio areas for further study. SOMA1001 and SOMA1002 courses are complementary and may be completed in any order.

of Arts, Design and Architecture","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOMA2408 - Time, Mass and Motion in Analogue and Digital Animation","description":"

What is the relationship between time and mass and the creation of animated movement? How do time and mass relate to one another to create a visual language instantly understood merely by the shaping of time through animation? 


In this course you will investigate the concepts of 'time envelopes' which are a unit of movement that has been shaped to express the intention and consciousness of a character or natural phenomena. You will also investigate how real world forces of weight and energy can be translated into animated sequences.  This will be achieved through stop-frame workshops and projects that focus and single out movement and it's translation into animation.  You will further explore how time can be reshaped into the consciousness of a character so that, for instance, a simple pause becomes the character considering something, an alternating pattern of time and movement becomes hesitation. These concepts will be applied to a set of 2D digital animation formats.


The course is the study of how the basic elements of movement, mass, momentum, inertia and decay of energy can express a sense of presence in a character or a process in nature. The course will also conduct further experiments into, for instance, how sound can focus attention on unseen movement, the nature of screen time, and different ideation skills.  There will be an emphasis on developing a timing style and focus on what is possible (and not so possible) in any shot, scene or whole narrative arc.

There should be two characters and care should be given to create sequences that express a wide range of movement and timing potential.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOMA2409 - Animated Worlds","description":"

Animated Worlds offers a practical introduction to the fundamental aspects of creating a sense of 'worlds' through the creation and manipulation of moving environments. Environments not only act as backgrounds to works, they also create the sense of place that is fundamental to the experience of animated realities.

You will learn to create immersive animated environments that will create a memorable experience for the viewer. You will create in-camera-pans (as per the shifting world of Caroline Leaf and William Kentridge), manipulate multi-plane cameras (as per the mechanical world of Anthony Lucas, Oscar Fischinger and Japanese post-apocalyptic anime) and create abstracted spaces (the projected work of Daniel Crooks and Max Hattler) by experimenting with stop-motion and digital technologies.

You will be able to apply knowledge acquired from this course across a range of BMA and BFA courses where cinematic space is produced and/or researched through artistic practice. This is a complementary course to SOMA2411 CGI Lens, SOMA2410 The 3D animated Body, SOMA2408 Time and Mass and motion.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c7540454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619c6","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Shifting spaces: Short animation and presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"45","description":"

In this rotoscope exercise, you will explore the process of straight-ahead animation by drawing and erasing scenes of domestic spaces. Everyday events will be re-imaged through drawing the subject in relation to its urban environment. You will identify an ‘event’ and record it on video (audio and visual capture). You will construct a narrative from your experience of witnessing this event and re-create it showing different points of view. Each version will illuminate specific areas of interest for the viewer at that given point in time.

There will be an in-depth analysis of the work of William Kentridge and Caroline Leaf whose politics and aesthetics are expressed through the medium itself: the way in which the process of animation is exposed, images erased and then redrawn. Students will create their work using rotoscoping and drawn techniques to create short animated sequences that explore the theme of event and memory. Final duration approximate 1 minute.

Students will upload their works to Moodle or the Classwork server prior to class. Each work will be presented to the class and the student will be required to speak about their project for 5 minutes.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0b540454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619c8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"07540454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619d0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Animated Worlds Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Select two short animated films that you have been shown in week 1 and 2. Compare how they use the medium of animation to communicate narrative and emotion through distorted and abstracted environments. What techniques do the animator use to establish their ‘world’ in order to reorient the viewer to experience the world according to its own set of rules?

Your response should include the titles of the films you have selected to analyse. You must mention at least 2 animation principles outlined in Week 1 of this course. Try to show how the medium of animation exploit principles of animation and metamorphosis to communicate in a way that live-action cannot. What is unique to the medium of animation and what kinds of themes lend themselves to the medium of animation? How are these themes expressed through animation aesthetics and techniques?

Maximum 1000 word essay submitted via Moodle as a PDF document. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"03540454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619c9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0f540454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619cd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Environment and affect – short animation and presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will use images of their local environments and/or miniature sets to create a video composite of a landscape that triggers an affective response in the viewer. Your aim is to collectively design an animated/augmented landscapes that express an emotion. You should use sound and composited images to create affect; eg. Use of debris/visualizing wastelands to convey desolation/despair; or the use of nature/natural to express serenity and peacefulness. You are required to incorporate your visual research into your final animated project so that the world that you present clearly articulates a time and place. Images will be layered and extended by means of compositing and/or digital painting with consideration being given to its relationship with movement. Final duration approximate 1 minute.

You will receive both a group and individual mark for this assessment. Your group mark will be based on the creative output (15%). Your individual mark will be based on individual presentation (15%).  

Students will upload their a preview/rough-cut of their works to Moodle or the Classwork server prior to class. Each work will be presented to the class and students will be required to speak about their project and their individiual contribution for 5 minutes and participate in group feedback. The final short animation will be due in week 11.

contentlets.keywords: media arts,animation,matte painting,compositing,cinematic space,animation in media arts,surrealist animation,illustration
contentlets.description:
Animated Worlds offers a practical introduction to the fundamental aspects of creating a sense of 'worlds' through the creation and manipulation of moving environments. Environments not only act as backgrounds to works, they also create the sense of place that is fundamental to the experience of animated realities.

You will learn to create immersive animated environments that will create a memorable experience for the viewer. You will create in-camera-pans (as per the shifting world of Caroline Leaf and William Kentridge), manipulate multi-plane cameras (as per the mechanical world of Anthony Lucas, Oscar Fischinger and Japanese post-apocalyptic anime) and create abstracted spaces (the projected work of Daniel Crooks and Max Hattler) by experimenting with stop-motion and digital technologies.

You will be able to apply knowledge acquired from this course across a range of BMA and BFA courses where cinematic space is produced and/or researched through artistic practice. This is a complementary course to SOMA2411 CGI Lens, SOMA2410 The 3D animated Body, SOMA2408 Time and Mass and motion.
contentlets.title: Animated Worlds

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOMA2410 - The 3D Animated Body","description":"

The 3D Animated Body will expose you to the sculptural space of 3D CGI computer animation in order to explore virtual movement, constructed timing and animated object agency. You will analyse how 3D movement differs from 2D movement, explore the possibilities and challenges of working in 3D space and investigate relationships between the neurological processes involved in 'visual motion perception' and the animated gesture.


Assessment in this course includes research and analysis on how 3D movement is perceived, interpreted and applied to the animated body in order to perform virtual movement that can communicate complex human emotions.  You will explore movement in the animated body through evaluation, presentation and exercises using provided character(s) and other prepared objects.


The 3D Animated Body relates to companion courses in the Animation & VFX 'stream' within the Bachelor of Media Arts by providing an understanding of animating gesture and agency in 3D space. This course will prepare students to undertake level 3000 courses that require grounding in 3D CGI research and practice in animation.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6b544454dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961961","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Gesture Animation - The Body in Motion","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"Student will explore the foundations of movement through the animated gesture. Using a supplied 3D CGI character students will develop a fully constructed and animated action based on 'codified movement' interpreted and applied to the character through a deeper understanding of human motion perception; in particular on the detection and reading of human physical movement. The human mind is highly tuned to detect 'life' through movement, the animator constructs a codified series of movements that need not directly relate to real-world human physical movement. Animators trigger a perceptual response through the animated performance. Students should adopt an experimental approach and respond to the research and activities covered throughout the course.
Students are graded [ /50] and offered written feedback using the following marking rubric: 1. The quality of the animation response - does the movement show or generate a response based on a successful interpretation of codified movement? 2. Relevant theoretical or contextual interpretation of the reading â?? does the response adequately address the reading on human motion perception?","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e3544454dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961963","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"eb544454dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961963","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"67544454dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961967","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online reflective learning","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"A reflective online journal is a location for you to track your classwork and associated project development from beginning to end and include details of any research, tutorials, successes and difficulties encountered along the way. The practice of reflective learning through an active journal is a process supported by many higher education specialists including Stephen Brookfield and Garry Rolfe. A successful reflective online journal needs to have entries made on a weekly basis that provide opportunity for critical reflection on your learning process.
Feedback will take the form of online comment from the instructor and periodic evaluation on the reflective practice in weeks three, six and thirteen. Evaluations from the instructor will be sent out to students via unimail in weeks four, seven and fourteen.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"eb544454dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961963","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6f544454dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961964","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Identifying the Gesture","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"Students will explore how 3D animated spaces differ from 2D through evaluation of the 'animated gesture'. Almost all screen based projections end up on 2D screens, 2D animated approaches generate their own set of rules for the representation of animated gesture; how does the addition of a third dimension add to the readability of a 3D character performance and how does this effect the animation style? Students will break down and identify codified movement through the animated gesture on a supplied 3D CGI character and performance based recorded dialogue. Using a limited number of poses (stepped of blocked action only, as spline based animation will distract from the readability), students will investigate what the animated gesture is. Student will submit their findings to the class group in short presentations that reflect on the research activities and reading supplied over the preceding weeks.
Each presentation will gain feedback from peers and tutor immediately following each presentation. In addition, Students are graded [ /30] and offered written feedback using the following marking rubric: 1. Conceptual coherence â??does the presentation represent an understanding of the readingâ??s content and arguments? 2. Relevant theoretical or contextual interpretation â?? does the presentation display an adequate research and an understanding of the researchâ??s relevance.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"eb544454dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"eb544454dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961963","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bf544454dbb1fc90be4672f5f396196a","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/SOMA2410.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

The use of CGI (Computer Generated Imagery) and VFX (Visual Effects) is no longer exclusive to its cinematic origins. Through experimental film and media art applications it continues to evolve in dynamic ways. Artists increasingly incorporate CGI and VFX into installations and exhibitions, architects use it to create visualisations of space in time, and scientists use it to interpret abstract concepts for a breadth of uses from microbiology through to nanotechnologies. CGI Lens Lab is aimed at exploring its many forms and applications across a wide range of creative and professional practice. You will engage in discussion and research as well as experimental studio exercises. Removed from the constraints of capturing reality, you will look at how CGI can become a fertile ground for experimentation.


This course involves analysis of 3D Animation aesthetics and techniques through the lens of Visual Effects and contemporary media practice. You will be encouraged to use hybrid techniques to build your capacity in animation. This course compliments other courses within Video, Sound and Image and Animation and Visual Effects.

Within this project they will also look at how CGI, being removed from the constraints of capturing reality, makes it a furtile ground for experimentation. They will also examine how it can break with this traditional emphasis on story and realism to explore new forms and meaning. Through the exploration of CGI camera matching, lighting and rendering techniques the student will create a plausible match between 3D CGI elements and a still or moving image.
Students will participate in group feedback with the tutor. There will also be formative assessment through the weekly individual feedback in tutorials and class discussion/feedback as well as summative feedback at the conclusion of the project.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"10644454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619f4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"18644454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619f3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"50644454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619f9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"This assessment comprises research into contemporary artists, writers and practitioners working experimentally, conceptually; and who reference and incorporate CGI and Visual Effects traditions, materials and techniques in their practice. The practice of reflective learning through an active journal process is supported by many higher education specialists including Stephen Brookfield and Garry Rolfe. A successful reflective journal needs to have entries made on a weekly basis that provide opportunity for critical reflection on your learning process.
Feedback will take the form of comments from the tutor and periodic evaluation on the reflective practice throughout the semester.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"10644454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619f3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"10644454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619f4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d8644454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619fc","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/SOMA2411.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOMA2412 - Video Document","description":"

Video Document is an introductory video production course that aims to develop fundamental skills in creating video documentaries, while engaging with issues around accuracy, authority, editorial and the manufacture of belief.


You will choose and research a topic pitch a proposal to produce a video documentary covering your findings, then practice creating an 'objective' and 'accurate' presentation of your chosen subject as a short video. You'll then be asked to examine your work and that of your peers for bias and inaccuracy, and so to question the ideal of absolute truthfulness implied by the documentary form.


You will then pitch and produce a second video work employing tactics of propaganda, essaying a topic as seen from your personal viewpoint. This will allow questions of how media technology confirms belief to be addressed.

From these exercises you will be able gauge the appropriate and effective use of video in your own documentation and be better prepared to 'read between the lines' of video essays made by others.



This course relates to companion courses in sound production and imaging. It's useful for any student involved in video documentation and production research, in that it provides fundamental skills in production while clarifying the advantages and intellectual pitfalls involved.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"38648454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619a9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"2a Research and Pitch Non-Objective Documentary","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"Working in groups of 3-4, students decide upon a non-objective viewpoint and a line of argument by which that viewpoint may be presented. The widest range of views will be allowed but must be checked with the tutor before the pitch that they are not offensive to the university community or too trivial to provide an argument. The group must collect expert opinion and data in support of the viewpoint and declare the appropriate style of presentation, for example observational, or poetic. A shooting schedule is organised by the group. The group will pitch a video of no more than 5 minutes to the class and tutor, acting as a commissioning agent. The group must describe the viewpoint, the style, their line of argument, detail the tactics that they intend to employ and make a clear account of how these tactics distort, condense or otherwise vary from the ideal of accuracy. They must describe the visual language to be used in these tactics and the use of sound and music. The tutor guides the groups in planning subtle and persuasive communication and the formation of belief. Legal and OHS issues will be discussed and procedures set out. The group will hand in the pitch presentation as well as a 500 word outline of the concept.
In the pitching process the tutor identifies gaps and problems in the planning and suggests ways to improve the production process. The group may be asked to clarify or justify their viewpoint, or may be guided to changing the topic to a more appropriate idea. The presentation gives peers a chance to hear the argument that will be made in the video and give feedback whether they are likely to be convinced by it. If there are OHS issues or legal concerns the tutor will describe the appropriate procedures.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"30648454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619aa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"30648454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"38648454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619aa","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8d648454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619b7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"2b Produce Non-Objective Documentary","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"Contingent on a successful pitch, the group will produce a video recording of no more than 5 minutes which essays the proposed viewpoint. The work should strive to: - convince a majority audience of the viewpoint by any means while reducing scepticism - evidence clear image and sound and good use of editorial - not be insensitive or discriminatory to the subjects and the topic by intent or by technical mistake. The video will screened in class for discussion and feedback and then handed to the tutor for assessment. All students shall hand in a 1000 word report detailing - their role in the production and any problems they addressed in group management - the practical learning they have drawn from the exercise - tactics they employed in making the work, their success or failure and how this informs their perception of other documentary video work
All the video works are screened in class and collected for viewing online. In the screening the tutor and peers provide comment and feedback about the quality of the production, how engaging the viewpoint has proved to be and to what extent they were able to discern attempts to mislead or enforce a way of seeing. In classes following the videos are analysed and compared to those of the first assessment task.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"30648454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619aa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"30648454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"38648454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619aa","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b0648454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619ac","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"1a Research and Pitch Objective Documentary","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"Working in groups of 3-4, students choose and then research a topic for a documentary work. They nominate an appropriate production style. Interview subjects and sources of data to be covered are identified, background information collected, interview questions collated and a shooting schedule is organised by the group. The group will pitch to the class a production concept with the tutor acting as commissioning producer. They should evidence their understanding of the topic and a focus appropriate to a video recording no more than 5 minutes in length. They should confirm interviewees and locations. The accuracy and objectivity of the work is discussed. OHS issues are negotiated with the tutor. Each group supplies a copy of their presentation and a written pitch of about 500 words summarising the worth of the work.
In the pitching process the tutor identifies gaps and problems in the planning and suggests ways to improve the production process. The group may be asked to further research an unclear aspect of the plan, or may be guided to changing the topic to a more appropriate idea. If there are OHS issues or legal concerns the tutor will describe the appropriate procedures. The apparent objectivity of the work is a specific point of discussion in this meeting. It should attempted in good faith.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"30648454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619aa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"30648454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619ab","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b4648454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619b4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"1b Produce Objective Documentary","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"Contingent on a successful pitch, the group will produce a video recording of no more than 5 minutes which covers the proposed topic. The work should strive to: - be accurate, not be misleading by accident or omission - evidence production skills - with clear image and sound and good use of editorial - not be insensitive or discriminatory to the subjects and the topic by intent or by technical mistake. The video will screened in class for discussion and feedback and then handed to the tutor for assessment. All students shall hand in a 1000 word report detailing - their role in the production and any problems they addressed in group management - the practical learning they have drawn from the exercise - problems with accuracy that they have encountered in making the work and how this affects their perception of other documentary video work
All videos will be screened to the class and made available online. In class the tutor and peers discuss the clarity of the communication, the use of the media to illustrate the ideas, the interviewing process and other factors that become apparent. Over the following weeks the class will examine their works and outside examples for the factors that cause inaccuracy. Questions are raised about the limits of the medium and the technical literacy of moving image.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"30648454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619aa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"30648454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619ab","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bc648454dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619b0","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/SOMA2412.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description:
Video Document is an introductory video production course that aims to develop fundamental skills in creating video documentaries, while engaging with issues around accuracy, authority, editorial and the manufacture of belief.

You will choose and research a topic pitch a proposal to produce a video documentary covering your findings, then practice creating an 'objective' and 'accurate' presentation of your chosen subject as a short video. You'll then be asked to examine your work and that of your peers for bias and inaccuracy, and so to question the ideal of absolute truthfulness implied by the documentary form.

You will then pitch and produce a second video work employing tactics of propaganda, essaying a topic as seen from your personal viewpoint. This will allow questions of how media technology confirms belief to be addressed.

From these exercises you will be able gauge the appropriate and effective use of video in your own documentation and be better prepared to 'read between the lines' of video essays made by others.

This course relates to companion courses in sound production and imaging. It's useful for any student involved in video documentation and production research, in that it provides fundamental skills in production while clarifying the advantages and intellectual pitfalls involved.
contentlets.title: Video Document

Sound Foundations is an introductory Level 2 course in the Bachelor Of Media Arts (Hons). It offers a broad-based practical introduction to the fundamental aspects of sound practice in the arts, resulting first in the creation of a standalone sound work. A research proposal then leads to the creation of the audio component of a multi-media artwork such as a screen-based media work; an installation; or a performance.


You will learn to record, edit, relocate, synthesise and resample sound; and examine the altered perceptions and meanings of sound acquired through these recontextualisations. You will then experiment with sequencing sound over time with regard to frequency, space, acknowledged contexts and repetition/rhythm. There is a central focus on how the recontextualisation and manipulation of sound over time differs from the manipulation and sequencing of the image; which will enable you to create audiovisual works rather than simply "adding" sound to image. 


This course works in tandem with companion courses in video production in the Bachelor of Media Arts. It's also useful for any student involved in audiovisual practice, whether in video, animation, cross-media or installation, in that it clarifies the unique aspects of expressing concepts in sound, thus enabling you to combine these with conceptual expression in other mediums, as well as providing fundamental audio production skills. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"56640854dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619af","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Sound Project 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"You will research, create and develop a self-chosen project that has been outlined in the earlier Project Plan. The project may be a standalone sound work; a soundtrack/sound design for an existing video or animation work; a sound component of a multimedia work or installation; or a sound component of a performance piece. Projects involving mediums other than sound are graded on the appropriateness and success of the relationship of the sound component to other components in realising the stated intention of the work.
Following the Project Plan, the tutor discusses the ongoing development of the project during particular class feedback times. You will present your work at least once as a work-in-progress during class time for tutor and class feedback. The finished work is once again presented to the class and tutor for feedback in the final class.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e6640854dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e6640854dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ee640854dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ee640854dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619b1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"22640854dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619b7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Sound Transformation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"You are supplied with a particular collection of sounds at the start of semester. In the context of class exercises you learn to edit, manipulate and sequence audio while examining the ways in which the original meanings of those sounds are affected by being displaced from their sources. Attention is paid to the fundamental characteristics of sound - frequency/pitch; spatial characteristics; intrinsic and created rhythm; and recontextualisation of initial sources. Outside of class time, you create a two minute piece from these manipulated sounds for class presentation and feedback.
The tutor gives feedback and advice to you during class exercises in the lead up to assessment. The tutor and class members also discuss the work at the presentation stage.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e6640854dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ee640854dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619b0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2e640854dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619bc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Sound Project Plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"You write a proposal outlining your aims for the second project, covering your conceptual premise; a proposed schedule of the tasks ahead; and a summary of what you perceive to be your needs in terms of technical learning and conceptual development. As part of this, you respond to a series of questions relating to these needs; and also contextualise your proposal in relation to at least two existing audio or audiovisual works by other artists. You also submit any work that has commenced on the project.
The proposal is discussed in consultation with the tutor, and approval is given to go ahead with the project, or alterations are requested. The tutor may also recommend further particular research into the medium(s) that you are engaging with.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e6640854dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e6640854dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619b1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a6640854dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619b3","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/SOMA2413.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description:
Sound Foundations is an introductory Level 2 course in the Bachelor Of Media Arts (Hons). It offers a broad-based practical introduction to the fundamental aspects of sound practice in the arts, resulting first in the creation of a standalone sound work. A research proposal then leads to the creation of the audio component of a multi-media artwork such as a screen-based media work; an installation; or a performance.

You will learn to record, edit, relocate, synthesise and resample sound; and examine the altered perceptions and meanings of sound acquired through these recontextualisations. You will then experiment with sequencing sound over time with regard to frequency, space, acknowledged contexts and repetition/rhythm. There is a central focus on how the recontextualisation and manipulation of sound over time differs from the manipulation and sequencing of the image; which will enable you to create audiovisual works rather than simply "adding" sound to image. 

This course works in tandem with companion courses in video production in the Bachelor of Media Arts. It's also useful for any student involved in audiovisual practice, whether in video, animation, cross-media or installation, in that it clarifies the unique aspects of expressing concepts in sound, thus enabling you to combine these with conceptual expression in other mediums, as well as providing fundamental audio production skills.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOMA2414 - Foundations of Digital Imaging","description":"

Foundations of Digital Imaging aims to develop your skills and critical knowledge in the fundamentals of digital imaging practice, providing guided experimentation with concepts related to image composite and construction. You will participate in both group and individual photo research projects, practicing the interrelationship of lens-based technologies, light, the application of colour theory, digital tool sets and printed media.


In a 'Virtual Worlds' project you will research the impact of surrealism on game culture, advertising, film-making and from your findings create a photo-media composition that portrays your own utopian or distopian reality.


Through a digital facial reconstruction exercise, you'll explore the ethical implications of digital photo manipulation and experiment with the flexible nature of identity as conveyed by the digital image.


In these exercises you will develop core skills useful in digital painting, photography, video and animation.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4f644854dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961942","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Identity","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

For the first project, you will work in class to develop what at first will look like a traditional self- portrait. The new image you produce will be a combination of you and a class mate digitally manipulated to make a new identity which will look familiar but is a new virtual identity. This project will explore notions of the variety of the image combining traditional studio lighting with digital photography and digital postproduction. The project production timeline will start in the lighting studio to produce a portrait of everyone in the class under the same exact lighting conditions. After finishing in the studio, the self-portrait and one of your selected class-mates will be digitally mapped together, retouched, color corrected and masked. The final successful image produced will look photographically real but will be of something that does not exist. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"87644854dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961944","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8f644854dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961944","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"03644854dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961947","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Object of Desire or Not…","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Utilising your skill sets in digital imaging and digital composite developed over this Foundations of Digital Imaging course; develop a poster print that explores notions of - Object of Desire. Desire, in its simplest form is a strong feeling of wanting to have something. Desire, can be seen as a consumer’s effected response to a perceived need, which has been established by corporations, governments, politicians, art directors, image- makers and marketers. This project requires you to develop an image that elicits desire in the viewer. Explore commercial advertising imagery and examine how a product is made to become Desirable. The project could be used to explore ideas of coercion how imagery is used to project an ideology. The Object of Desire project could also be used to elicit responses to, “objects” that are framed in a “desirable” manner, via creative manipulations of light, colour, form, shape, personality or place.

Or Not

Desire as sketched out above is one way to explore the final project; the inverse can also be approached, the Undesirable. Utilising your skill sets in digital imaging and digital composite developed over this Foundations  of Digital Imaging course; develop a poster print that explores notions of the Undesirable. The Undesirable can explore the reverse of what is considered a beautiful, sublime, desirable, within an image – i.e., the unpleasant, distasteful, unacceptable, off-putting, obnoxious, frightful, terrible, reprehensible, deplorable, appalling, unsettling, beyond the pale, vile sickening, nauseous, are some words that can be useful to interpret the Or Not component of the final project. There will be lectures that expand upon the ideas outlined above.

Suggested tool sets to utilise for the project include:

- Psychology of perception: how the image object is framed physically and perhaps ideologically, the angel of view, lighting, focus effects all conspire to develop a successful image.

- The Golden mean: balance and design of the image.

- Colour: the design of the colour IE complementary colour, harmonious colour, discordant colour, use a colour palette that will assist the concept of your imagery.

- Lighting: consider how the lighting of the imagery will help your project

- Iconic: iconic imagery is one that can live long in popular culture or historically and can be see to be a potently successful accomplishment in any creative work.

Note: The print is to be approximately A3 or larger in size but the exact proportions will depend on how you creatively determine the aspect ratio of your print.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"87644854dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961944","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"87644854dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961945","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8f644854dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961944","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8f644854dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961945","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"07644854dbb1fc90be4672f5f396194f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"When I'm 164","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This project will use the self-portrait once more but this portrait will be of you when you are 164 year of age. After developing digital skill sets in the first project, the second project will move on to develop pre-production planning, while building upon digital post production skills. The project will require researching and speculation on future culture, on fashion and just how to make a young person look very old. The pre-production will also require an appreciation of the post production digital manipulation process and what planning is needed to produce a successful outcome.

You will need to explore the visible effects of the ageing process and portrayals of old age in the history of photography and art practice. Examine connections between youth and classical ideas of beauty, theories of aesthetics and attempts to preserve youth through surgery and medicine. It should convey not just the technical effects of ageing, but in design and execution address some or all of the ideas that you have collected in your research. The portrait should locate the subject into the future, what signals, what visual clues will be used to indicate the future that your portrait occupies?

Have a look around there are no 164 year old people in existence, as yet, so you will need to be creative, invent something, that, via your digital imaging skills will be convincing.  

The lecturer will guide and assists your learning and experimentation in achieving the goals of the work. The project will be addressed as part of the scheduled class lectures.

# Note: While developing the When I'm 164 project, remember it is not a project in attaching any form of robotic or mechanical apparatus to your ageing face. The project is asking you to explore notions of aging and the action of time on the body it is unacceptable to have a face that has no indication of aging.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"87644854dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961944","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8f644854dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961944","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8f644854dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961945","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8b644854dbb1fc90be4672f5f396194a","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/SOMA2414.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOMA2415 - Narrative Structures in Moving Image","description":"

Narrative Structures in Moving Image
introduces the history and practice of storytelling,
especially in video and sound production. The aim is for you to gain practice in a set of skills useful across media arts, but also to develop a critical approach to the constraints of industry norms.

The lectures will detail theories of story and dramatic production from Aristotle through
to current Hollywood story mechanics, and clarify their historical
and social assumptions. There will be emphasis on the depth of these structures, from their psychological basis up
to the practical 'recipes' now used in mainstream film.

At the same time you'll work on the writing, scripting, pre-production and shooting of a dramatic video narrative according to 'best practice' in current screen production. Each sub task will be based on the traditions and current expectations of the screen industry. At the end of this process you will have the experience to judge when these structures are useful for your own productions, and when breaking the rules is more effective.

Students in the Bachelor of Media Arts taking the Video, Sound and Image studio may follow with the companion 3000 level course
"Critiques of Narrative" which extends this critique into practice in new forms of storytelling - non linear, multiple screen, interactive and so on.

The course is useful for any student that requires a cultural and
historical perspective of storytelling aligned with practical experience
in narrative video writing and production.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ef644854dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619fd","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Story Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

You will individually research and design a story that can be told in video production. The story should follow structures described in the presentations leading up to the proposal - it should for example involve a motivated protagonist and some form of conflict with an antagonist or situation. It should be appropriate to a short running time of around 5 minutes.

The proposal requires the presentation of standard documentation, some of which (such as a Lead Line and character sketches) will be used in a presentation, and some of which will form written documentation handed to the tutor. The exact requirements will be set out in class. You will also need to be ready to answer questions about your story idea, such as its response to the expectations of the viewing audience.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2f644854dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619fe","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2b648854dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961904","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Pitch Video Production","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Starting from one or more successful story pitches you will work in a group to prepare full preproduction documentation for a video shoot. There should be at least a formal script, a breakdown of assets, storyboard and a shooting schedule. There should be clear characterization and proposed assignment of actors. OHS and legal requirements must be set out.

This task prepares for a risk-managed, successful production which coordinates individual effort and allows time for experimentation and 'what if' ideas. You avoid unknowns that will reduce the quality of the work. You practice the level of documentation that is expected for a professional production. All documents are to be presented in summary to the class and then submitted online. The tutor may at this stage ask the group to re-submit if the material does not meet the requirements.

In addition to the group presentation and documentation, this task also requires you to submit an individual action plan outlining your specific roles, responsibilities, and action items for contributing to the group production. This individual plan should clearly outline your role in the group production and demonstrate your understanding of how your individual contribution will assist in the development of a quality creative outcome.

Weighting:  50% Group mark - Adaptation and Documentation/Presentation, 50% Individual mark - Action Plan

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2f644854dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2f644854dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619ff","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"33648854dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961907","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Short Video Narrative and Reflective Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

The group produces a video of no more than 5 minutes duration. The work is screened for the class and then placed online for all in the course to see. The result is assessed for quality and compared to your planned content, mindful of translations that necessarily take place between writing and moving image. In the screening the tutor and your peers discuss these translations and may point out problems with your process.

As part of the group project, you will be assessed for the quality of both the overall work, and your individual contribution to it. For this reason, it is important to clearly define roles and responsibilities early in the production, and to develop collaborative skills to work well as a group.

As part of your individual contribution, you will submit a 1000-word report reflecting on your experiences and role in the production. Your report should detail how your creative and technical skills have developed throughout the project, and how you have contributed to the final outcome. In undertaking this task, it is recommended that you keep a journal or record of the steps you took to research and develop your role in the production. Reflecting on mistakes and misadventures can also allow you to develop depth in your report. It is important to clearly outline the specific roles and responsibilities you assumed throughout the production, and what you have learnt as a result of the group project.

Weighting: 33% Group - Storytelling and Production Cohesion, 67% Individual - Production Role and Reflective Report

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOMA2416 - Video Mapping into Sculptural Objects and 3D Spaces","description":"



Video Mapping into Sculptural Objects and 3D Spaces is a studio course that considers video projection as an art form. It situates itself neatly between contemporary installation and the projected image. Students will be encouraged to explore the possibilities of discretely mapping 'light' into spaces and onto objects. Through the creation of their own projects, students will learn about how objects react to light and colour. They will learn to assess objects from a projection perspective and develop skills that will enable them to combine real objects with projection and to think critically about the possibilities for these combinations. By the end of this course students will be able to analyse potential sites and see projects from pre-visualisation to conclusion.

contentlets.description: Video Mapping into Sculptural Objects and 3D Spaces is a studio course that considers video projection as an art form. It situates itself neatly between contemporary installation and the projected image. Students will be encouraged to explore the possibilities of discretely mapping 'light' into spaces and onto objects. Through the creation of their own projects, students will learn about how objects react to light and colour. They will learn to assess objects from a projection perspective and develop skills that will enable them to combine real objects with projection and to think critically about the possibilities for these combinations. By the end of this course students will be able to analyse potential sites and see projects from pre-visualisation to conclusion.
contentlets.title: Video Mapping into Sculptural Objects and 3D Spaces

contentlets.description: SOMA2481 Future Screen studies recent and historical examples of science fiction cinema and related critical discourses. The cinematic works include feature films & fictive documentaries, animations and related creative practices such as video art that encompass aspects of science fiction and related genres including horror and fantasy.  Students will view and discuss these examples with reference to a set of readings that will support the creation of a research diary relating to individual areas of studio practice. This diary will then form the basis for a variety of creative responses that can include the creation of a treatment, outline for a studio project, the completion of a related studio project, and/or a comprehensive research essay .
contentlets.title: Future Screen: Practices of Speculative Media

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOMA2605 - Lighting","description":"

This course focuses on lighting the digital environment and is designed to explore the role in relation to digital production in particular. Areas addressed include: the consistency of light, the fall of light, lighting for multiple outcomes, the measurement of light, key lighting and light ratios. In addition students will understand concepts such as colour temperature in relationship to available light, artificial light, and the nature of studio lighting, both tungsten and electronic. Students completing this course will enhance their understanding and appreciation of the role light plays in the image making process.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"15c488d4dbb1fc90be4672f5f396192e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tribute to a Master","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

As a form of mentorship, you will research and emulate a selected “master” of light. Pick an artist, photographer or filmmaker that has used lighting as a creative element and imitate their lighting design. Also consider the cultural implications of the work being mimicked. While “light” is a primary consideration for this project, the cultural narrative is important.

While Bill Henson’s work is immediately recognizable because of his use of light, there are infinitely more social and cultural themes at play that inform his work. Spielberg’s Close Encounters of the Third Kind (deemed "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant" by the United States Library of Congress), is a film that uses “light” almost as a character unto itself within the film.

Be strategic when picking something to emulate – as we don’t have a $20 million budget to work with. Research the image that you will emulate and develop lighting diagrams and calculate the manageability of the project. If you choose to work in the landscape, you may need to spend time in the field waiting for the light to arrive at the right time and place. Ansel Adams was known to wait weeks, sometime years to capture his favorite places. Sometimes it can happen very quickly without warning; a famous Adams photograph “Moonrise over Hernandez, NM” was made after screeching his car to a stop after noticing the fall of light while driving, with only a few minutes to make his image.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"51c488d4dbb1fc90be4672f5f396192f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"51c488d4dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961930","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"59c488d4dbb1fc90be4672f5f396192f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d1c488d4dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961931","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Blocking with light","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Cinematography is photography over time. A major issue is that the subject doesn’t stay nicely posed in the ‘sweet spot’ of our design, they move about causing hotspots, shadows and temperature changes. We’ll simplify this problem into a case where the subject moves from one set up to another. That is, they are blocked to be lit by one design and then move to a different set up. Between these we will portray an arc – a small change of circumstance, or of characterization.

You are required to:

  • storyboard a small, continuous scene where a character, or characters move from one lighting atmosphere to another, for example, from outside to inside, or from anxiety to a resolution, or the impression of a passing day, or even a monstrous change of physical appearance, such as Jekyll and Hyde.
  • It is important that the design allows a smooth transition, without hotspots, drops in level or other unwanted distractions. You should spend time researching the methods that will best suit the idea.
  • Set up the lights and record a short video that captures your scene. The scenery and props are not important – we are concerned only with how light is telling the story.
  • Edit the video if required and deliver as a MP4 file no longer than 2 minutes.
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"51c488d4dbb1fc90be4672f5f396192f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"51c488d4dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961930","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"59c488d4dbb1fc90be4672f5f396192f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d5c488d4dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961939","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Drawing with Light, in the Night","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

‘Drawing with Light, in the Night’ will be made at night with no or limited light and uses as a starting point the meaning of photography – to ‘draw with light’. The canvas for the project will be the nocturnal. You will construct an image that is illuminated by time & light:

  • the length of time the camera is left open to permit light to fall on the sensor and be recorded, 
  • the quality of light that is introduced into the scene. Introduced light can include torches, streetlights, house lights, fluorescent lights, and portable flash. The color temperature of the artificial light must be taken into account as it will impact the nature of the work.

This project asks you to explore the magic of light at night. Image making at night starts with darkness and then builds an image with the controlled introduction of light to the scene. You are encouraged to make experimental works using combinations of time and light to determine the appropriate exposures, including the look and feel to your work.

In this studio workshop the student is introduced to the basic concepts and future possibilities of digital imaging processes. The emphasis is on the integration of digital technologies into visual arts practices. The subject opens up for consideration a range of digital applications suitable for extending image production and visualisation. The student is introduced to the practice and methods of production of contemporary artists who utilise a variety of digital technologies in their work.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOMA2818 - Media Apps and Digital Publication","description":"

Media Apps and Digital Publication is designed for Art & Design students, particularly those involved in screen production, seeking to present their work in new media spaces. It's of interest to anyone that seeks to publish their outcomes in responsive formats for entertainment, research, public relations, training or other media needs. It addresses current trends in electronic media publication; mobile and wearable devices, cloud services, smart screens and so on. These venues have a growing audience, where traditional venues such as books and cinema are in decline.


Completion of the course will assist you to design your creative works for interaction, to publish research in new ways to more audiences, to develop teaching and learning tools for secondary education and help engineer better tools for artistic expression.


Useful entry skills include photography, writing, typography and layout. This elective does not require programming skills, but may be useful to computer science students who want more experience and collaboration in digital publishing formats.

Publish Final Work","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Respond to peer feedback and refine the work to be self evident. That is, it should not require that you explain its use, and it should provide a familiar metaphor for its operation. Improve the user experience, finalise an appropriate design aligned with the content.

Publish the work using the appropriate service (could be iBooks, Creative Cloud etc.) and direct peers and tutor to this service.

Describe your experience in producing the work and suggest how the tools and medium might be improved.


The project is assessed as an offering on the appropriate service, evidencing its design and purpose. It is assessed on (a) communication of the intent (b) design aesthetics (c) use of the medium (d) critique of the new media.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"72c40cd4dbb1fc90be4672f5f396192d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"72c40cd4dbb1fc90be4672f5f396192e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7ac40cd4dbb1fc90be4672f5f396192d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"36c40cd4dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961935","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"1. Research and Propose Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Survey existing work in the field of digital publishing, identify examples that inform the design of a new work. Critique the examples for aspects which limit the artistic and communication potential of a new work. Put forward a proposal for a project using digital publishing effectively and appropriately. The proposal should include interface sketches and a flowchart of functionality.


Presentation to peers and tutor for feedback, collaborative ideas and error checking. Immediate verbal assessment followed by marking via Review.

Demonstrate Design and Interface","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Design an appropriate interface for the project, including the layout design, navigation, media, and metaphor. The publication may be a rough concept at this point but the author should be able to describe the limitations and how they will be addressed. Playtest this interface with peers. Resolve any confusing or inappropriate features.

Demonstrate the interface to peers as a 'rough cut' of the final work.


Presentation to peers and tutor for feedback, collaborative ideas and error checking. Immediate verbal assessment followed by marking via Review.

contentlets.description:
Media Apps and Digital Publication is designed for Art & Design students, particularly those involved in screen production, seeking to present their work in new media spaces. It's of interest to anyone that seeks to publish their outcomes in responsive formats for entertainment, research, public relations, training or other media needs. It addresses current trends in electronic media publication; mobile and wearable devices, cloud services, smart screens and so on. These venues have a growing audience, where traditional venues such as books and cinema are in decline.

Completion of the course will assist you to design your creative works for interaction, to publish research in new ways to more audiences, to develop teaching and learning tools for secondary education and help engineer better tools for artistic expression.

Useful entry skills include photography, writing, typography and layout. This elective does not require programming skills, but may be useful to computer science students who want more experience and collaboration in digital publishing formats.
contentlets.title: Media Apps and Digital Publication

contentlets.keywords: media arts,media histories,media art,asian video art,asian visual cultures,installation art in asia,asian art cinema
contentlets.description: Media Art in Asia is an elective course that explores contemporary media art practices and innovation in Asian visual cultures. The course will be of interest to students seeking to understand regional and global media art and its emergence in the countries of East, South and Southeast Asia. Through practice-based case studies of video art, photography, participatory art, installations and art cinema from Asia, the course will explore themes such as migration, diaspora, the influence of Asian pop and fantasy genres, war and memory, locality and place-making, cultural traffic and borderless media. Students will have the opportunity to respond to these themes via their artistic practice. Course assessment includes a creative practical component, such as a self-initiated artwork and/or curatorial project of peer work presented for peer discussion and class feedback.
contentlets.title: Media Art in Asia

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOMA3408 - Animation Processes: Preproduction to Post","description":"

Animation Processes: Preproduction to Post offers an indepth exploration of the complete cycle of animation processes using a range of materials, data and digital technologies to create a short self-contained animated project reflecting an inventive approach to process. This will involve research, creative ideation and visual experimentation plus a focus on managing the specific requirements for project planning and preproduction, animation development and production, as well as post-production to generate a finished work ready for viewing by an audience.


To successfully take a creative idea for animation to completion requires familiarity with the overall process and signficant preproduction planning. You will work collaboratively to brainstorm concepts for your animated project then draft and redraft a high quality script and storyboard to distill your idea into a form suitable for a pitch or funding application. This includes a proof of concept based on significant visual and textual research with documention for a unique method suited to bring your project to fruition. You will analyse how processes impact on creative workflow, the importance of R&D (research and development) and reflect on how these iterative processes help to improve the quality of your original idea and can be used to generate and refine new ideas for further animation projects.

honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"SOMA3410","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOMA3410 - Performative Animation and the Virtual Body","description":"

Performative Animation and the Virtual Body will help you to bring your animated characters to life. In this course you will learn how identity is communicated through the animated body and how animators engage with performance as an animation process. Assessment involves the creation and evaluation of a character performance that aims to show 'embodied agency' through animated movement; including body, voice, and facial expressions.


You will explore how animated agency is generated by analysing a combination of performance and acting skills, which can then be applied in your creative work using advanced 3D CGI character animation techniques. In particular, you will focus on developing emotive strategies for your character, based on physiological and psychological devices, included in physical performance processes. You will investigate nuances of physical expression through observation of performances in character animation, undertaking experimental body animation, and participating in live-performances that integrate digital technologies.


 


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6f15c858dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619f8","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Speak To Me (facial animation)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

In this project you will progressively explore, develop and refine a physical performance that generates emotional engagement with your audience through the animated control of your character's face and lip-synced performance. You will analyse and synthesise the finer nuances of facial and vocal performance that successfully communicate emotional intent. Building on your developing knowledge of technique and application in facial animation, you will create a short head-only animated performance to an approved audio dialogue that addresses emotional content via physiognomy and vocal performance.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a315c858dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619fa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ab15c858dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619f9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6315c858dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619fc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"The Animator and Audience Loop","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

In this extended project you will construct a physical performance that generates emotional engagement with your audience through the combined control of your character's physical, facial and vocal performance. Building on your amalgamated practice and research, you will synthesise, manipulate, and skilfully realise a short character-based animated performance that addresses emotional content and intent of a pre-recorded audio dialogue.

In your process diary you will document your approach, and evidence your research and thinking underpinning the emotional performance, and intention, for your animated character performance.
