Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOMA3411 - Visual Effects Project","description":"

In the Visual Effects Project you will examine how CGI and Visual Effects (VFX) strategies are used to realize ideas not easily documented in other media forms, such as video or photography. Working in teams to review current case studies and explore what is possible in Visual Effects, you will look at the various ways these possibilities are integrated with animation. In particular, you will focus on 3D modelling, 3D texturing, marking and tracking data in video footage and other integration methods between 3D CGI and real video footage, in order to negotiate relevant processes for undertaking a collaborative VFX project.


You will learn how to coordinate the workflow and methods needed in both areas of studio practice. This helps to prepare you for managing the challenges involved in completing a major work in the following Honours year.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"88250c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f396199f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual Research Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

For this assessment, you will be required to undertake research within the realm of 3D Computer Generated Imagery (CGI) and visual effects that will inform the area of exploration for your individual project (Assessment2). Choose either two artists/practitioners or two projects, one of which must be more experimental, meaning they work with unique, innovative techniques or aesthetics and work against traditional film narrative methods.  The second is a selection of your choice as long as it supports your area of exploration.

From this research, you will create a presentation for class Week 3 with visual support (not limited to images and video in PowerPoint, word or pdf format) to illustrate how this will relate to what you are doing. Detail the relationship between the works you have researched and what you are undertaking.

Consider the following:

How does the project you have chosen work with CGI or visual effects? Explore in detail the techniques giving the tutorial class a mini lesson how the technique works. How will you utilise both the thematic and/or practical approaches and how will this that be similar to your work? What are you doing that is unique? How is the work you are doing going to approach quality of submission and originality? How will the work you are doing contribute to the brief? Where does your work lie, within the realm of industry practice or more experimental media arts?

Submission details:

Submit presentation material as PowerPoint to Moodle before class. Provide full references and labelling for all images, video and theoretical works cited. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c4250c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619a0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"84250c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619a3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research and development prototype","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

You will begin your process by brainstorming and developing a project that is in line with your practice, whether that be a short 3D CGI or an interactive/VR project. This project will require you to take the skills you have learned so far and combine them with the other stream of knowledge that you are focusing on in your degree. It is recommended that you focus the research (from Assessment 1) into a component of the production process that you will need to understand in order to proceed with this project. At that stage in consultation with your tutor, you must decide whether it is feasible within the 10 week timeframe.

Continuing on from the research you have undertaken in Assessment 1, and keeping in mind your Assessment 3 project you will conceptually design and prototype your project. This concept design will include (but is not limited to) photographs, collected materials, concept sketches, sketches, modelling sketches, test renders, mood boards and texture samples and any experimentation done so far within the software package/s.

You are required to negotiate this component with your tutor before week 5. Your prototype will be a either one of the following depending on the type of project you are creating:

1)     A fully rendered one frame test of the complete look of your project including composite grade and effects.

2)     An animated section of the work which could be final timing with sound

3)     A final Unreal /Unity scene or layout of the scene with relevant cameras or initial coding aspects that will define the final project.

4)     An alternative as defined by you and your tutor in consultation and with review of course assessment criteria.

Submission details:

This will include two components

1)     Concept document of two pages, including images and aspects mentioned above that are relevant to the project you are creating. It must be relevant to the kind of production process you are working with.

2)     Rendered or otherwise defined prototype where a small component is considered fully aesthetically completed (look development complete and applied) an acts as a guide for the rest of the project.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c4250c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619a0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c4250c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619a1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"cc250c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619a0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cc250c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619a1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8c250c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619a5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"VFX Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Using your project prototype from assessment 2, you are required to design and produce a final project (3D CGI/VFX or AR/VR/XR Project) that acts as a work suitable for installation in the Blackbox.

You will begin your process by brainstorming and developing this project in Assessment 2. Working individually as well as with both peer and tutor discussion, devise a short project that is achievable in the 10 week course using the skills and knowledge around advanced CGI and VFX techniques.

More detail around the project and the brief will be provided in class and on Moodle.

Submission details:

Via Moodle and the classwork server, see Moodle Assessment FAQ.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOMA3412 - Critiques of Narrative in Moving Image","description":"

In Critiques of Narrative in Moving Image you will creatively critique the rules and limitations put forward by screen industry practice, considering whether breaking the rules has more efficacy when the paradigm is in place. In particular you will challenge prevailing expectations of screened media, examining ideas about the rearrangement of time, juxtaposition of sound and image, montage, multiple and split screens or the interactive control of video to demonstrate what can be done to expand on traditional film practice and ask why these tactics are necessary.

Assessment involves the active remaking or reform of an existing film or video work into a new, personalised short. Using processes such as editing, sound replacement, treatment and erasure you will make good use of the storytelling by moving image. By condensing it, media that was intended for a wide audience is reshaped into your personal vision with strong significance and personality, but not necessarily following a traditional arc. You will also create a new video work that conscientiously experiments with the expectations of cinema by questioning any or all of the elements including the time line, the story arc, screen format, engagement with the audience or characterisation - first declaring and then following clearly documented goals and methodology.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"64254c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961964","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Analysis and Resynthesis part 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"Once the proposed re-reading of the source film has been approved you may begin editing. There being no means to control the quality of the source material the technical quality of the result is less important than the idea which you convey. Nevertheless any reworking of the source that improves the image quality is recognised. The result should be a video programme 2 - 3 minutes in duration presented on a single screen (although it may make use of multiple images) with a soundtrack. Present in class for peer and tutor feedback. The marking rubric is: - The extent to which a new reading of the source is made evident to the audience. - The creative use of sound, editing and treatments to re-purpose the material. - The power of the message as now presented.
The videos are screened in class for group discussion about the process, results and reflection on the use and re-use of film language. The discussion should be playful and explorative and inspire expansive thinking.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"64254c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6c254c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961964","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"24254c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961967","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Form Follows Function part 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"The second project requires you to work in groups to create a video work that experiments with the expectations of cinema. It may question any or all of elements such as the time line, the story arc, screen format, engagement with the audience, characterisation and so on. There must however be a structure that guides the production. Before commencing production the group must declare an intent, survey existing film and video work that employs radical practice, and from that devise a method that would seem to best serve your intent. The resultant form of the video work should be shaped by the aims of the project above consideration of traditional practice. It is allowed that your experiment may not be successful in terms of audience expectations or industry standards, so long as it is internally valid. It is not sufficient to randomly try ideas. Present your proposal to the class for feedback. Assessment is based on: - The clarity of the idea being proposed as communicated in the presentation. - The evident connection between method and intention.
The group will present their concept to the class for feedback. The class should consider whether the form of the result will serve the function, and suggest ways to hone that principle. They should also watch for problems that might interfere with the completion of the work.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"64254c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6c254c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961965","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ac254c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f396196a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Analysis and Resynthesis part 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"In this project you will take an existing film or video work and by processes of editing, sound replacement, treatment and erasure reform it into a new, personalised short. This condensation takes media intended for a wide audience and remakes it as your personal vision. The result should evidence strong significance and personality. It need not follow a traditional arc, but it should still make good use of storytelling by moving image. Part one of the process involves analysing an existing film work. Select a film or video and watch it carefully. You are analysing the intention of the film maker(s) and the use of film language that conveys that intention. Identify those sections which are important for the current 'reading' of the film and how they operate. Decide on a personal 'reading' of these crucial sections. This need not be shared with other viewers but should be coherent and be able to be understood by them. You will submit a written plan for reworking the material to reveal the 'reading' that you wish to impose upon it (about 1000 words, illustrated). The plan should detail editing, sound work and treatments to the footage that will make your concept apparent. Present a section of the source to the class and briefly describe how you intend to rework it (5 mins). The assessment rubric is: - The clarity of the analysis of the source material as presented. - The coherence and feasibility of the planned reworking.
A quick presentation gives the student an idea of how their idea will translate to the viewer. If their peers do not understand the intent in the presentation then adjustments should be made before starting. The written proposal allows consideration of how carefully the student has analysed the existing work. Their reading may or may not be 'correct'; this matters less than they have thought carefully about the material with which they will work. It should be possible to give a response quickly based on how much effort has been put into the reading. If the student has great difficulty in understanding the project they have an opportunity to change paths before any academic penalty.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"64254c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6c254c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961964","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e4254c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f396196e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Form Follows Function part 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"Your group will present your completed work to the class for feedback. If the presentation requires special facilities such as multiple screens or surround audio you must arrange this before the due date. If the work is very long or infinite you should prepare an indicative sample. The period available for screening is about 5 minutes. The presentation will start with a quick outline of the piece that should be carefully prepared for maximum efficacy. You will then screen the piece and there will questions from the class. Each member of the group should prepare a small summary (about 1000 words) of their involvement in the process and their own learning outcomes. The marking rubric will be: - The extent to which the resulting piece adapts to the intent. - The quality of storytelling and communication. - The process as described in the written component.
The screening tests how well the completed work communicates with an audience. The ideal is that the novel format adds to comprehension of the idea, not obscures it. If the peers are confused by the piece they have a chance to question the makers and see where the problem lies. The small written component is useful in allowing each group member to think about their own learning. It also catches imbalances in the group work load. Following on from the screening the class will hold a debate in which traditional and experimental techniques are judged for their relevant strengths.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"64254c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6c254c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961965","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ec254c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961971","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/SOMA3412.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

In Critiques of Narrative in Moving Image you will creatively critique the rules and limitations put forward by screen industry practice, considering whether breaking the rules has more efficacy when the paradigm is in place. In particular you will challenge prevailing expectations of screened media, examining ideas about the rearrangement of time, juxtaposition of sound and image, montage, multiple and split screens or the interactive control of video to demonstrate what can be done to expand on traditional film practice and ask why these tactics are necessary.

Assessment involves the active remaking or reform of an existing film or video work into a new, personalised short. Using processes such as editing, sound replacement, treatment and erasure you will make good use of the storytelling by moving image. By condensing it, media that was intended for a wide audience is reshaped into your personal vision with strong significance and personality, but not necessarily following a traditional arc. You will also create a new video work that conscientiously experiments with the expectations of cinema by questioning any or all of the elements including the time line, the story arc, screen format, engagement with the audience or characterisation - first declaring and then following clearly documented goals and methodology.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOMA3413 - Audiovisual Studio","description":"

In this course, you will explore the role of sound design in constructing screen-based audiovisual work, looking at how the overall soundtrack acts as a storytelling component from preproduction to post-production in video and animation. By analysing the primacy of sound in forming connections between sequenced images and determining the pace and focus of the storytelling, you will analyse how sound can provide an important character perspective - rather than camera perspective - in both traditional and experimental moving image forms. This course will enable you to alter the perceptions and meanings of existing audiovisual work, referencing both the traditional Hollywood model and experimental variations of the audiovisual relationship. You will be involved in the scripting, planning and execution of sound design, with production of the soundtrack for audiovisual work using pre-existing video or animation components. Building on your previous studies, you will learn how to use sound studios, audio samplers and other creative tools to record and produce both stereo and surround sound by manipulating all layers of the soundtrack. The studio knowledge and audiovisual skills provided in this course expand on traditional and experimental techniques and concepts of storytelling relevant across a wide range of video, animation and cross-media practices.

contentlets.description: In this course, you will explore the role of sound design in constructing screen-based audiovisual work, looking at how the overall soundtrack acts as a storytelling component from preproduction to post-production in video and animation. By analysing the primacy of sound in forming connections between sequenced images and determining the pace and focus of the storytelling, you will analyse how sound can provide an important character perspective - rather than camera perspective - in both traditional and experimental moving image forms. This course will enable you to alter the perceptions and meanings of existing audiovisual work, referencing both the traditional Hollywood model and experimental variations of the audiovisual relationship. You will be involved in the scripting, planning and execution of sound design, with production of the soundtrack for audiovisual work using pre-existing video or animation components. Building on your previous studies, you will learn how to use sound studios, audio samplers and other creative tools to record and produce both stereo and surround sound by manipulating all layers of the soundtrack. The studio knowledge and audiovisual skills provided in this course expand on traditional and experimental techniques and concepts of storytelling relevant across a wide range of video, animation and cross-media practices.
contentlets.title: Audiovisual Studio

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOMA3414 - Rethinking Sound and Music","description":"

In Rethinking Sound and Music you will produce original sound/music works drawing on analysis of traditionally separated histories, genres and definitions of sound and music. In particular, you will examine the effect of technology on the subsequent formation of sound/music genres and their implicit structures, including the synthesis and remix of ideas, and the sampling and quotation of structure. The studio focus involves exploring shifting notions of authenticity in regards to the post-recorded instrument by examining ways in which the structures of creative audio practice oscillate between popular cultures and the avant-garde.


Building on your previous studies in relation to the composition of sound sequences, you will expand your skills in recording, synthesising, sampling and sequencing of audio by working in the sound recording studios to produce a sound/music work with a written analysis that contextualises your work within the histories of creative practice that it references. You will also create/remix a further work constructed from the work of your classmates.



","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"35258c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961998","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Your proposal should outline the types of procedures, experimentation and structure you propose to undertake in composing the work for Assessment task 3, including potential components, posisble sound sources and technical requirements/needs where relevant. You should also reference work by at least two other artists (with specific links and/or files), clearly explaining the relevance to your own work. This may involve you discussing similar or different approaches to the referenced artist. Discuss your previous work as a sound/music composer, if that exists (one again with specific links and/or files). As long as you include all of these things, you do not need to follow standards essay formats (footnoting etc.) - the clarity of your. intentions is what is most important here.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"35258c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961999","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f5258c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f39619a0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Sound composition","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

You will compose a sound/music work or group of works of any form, style or perceived genre(s); as supported by your research and contextualisation in Assessment Task 1. Time-based work (as opposed to non-timeline installation work) must be at least three minutes in length. Your project does not need to be directly associated with any particular forms, styles or histories examined in lectures or tutorials, rather, the lecture/tutorial content is intended to inspire you to look beyond mere emulation of sound/music fields via a deeper understanding of the processes by which compositional structures and genres are formed.

Submission details

Two submissions to the Classwork server folder :

- a .wav file of the current or final mix, named with your student number and name.

- A folder containing your session and all source material, also with your student number and name.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"35258c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f396199a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3d258c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961998","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3d258c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961999","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f9258c58dbb1fc90be4672f5f396199b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Sound Composition - Work in Progress","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This is a work-in-progress presentation of your sound composition. You are expected to have been experimenting with and developing your project over the month since the submission of the Project Proposal. You must also give a spoken introduction about the intentions and plans for the ongoing work, but also note how the project aims may have changed since the initial proposal. There will also be discussion with the teacher and class at the time of the presentation. 

Submission details

Two submissions to the Classwork server folder:

- a .wav file of the current or final mix, named with your student number and name

- a folder containing your session and all source material, also with your student number and name

honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"SOMA3415","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOMA3415 - Compositional Project","description":"

Compositional Project draws together your learning in sound, video and image production to experiment with and master individual approaches to visual and sonic composition. You will devise your own method and rules upon which the work will be based, acting as a 'composer'. You will be encouraged to declare a specific intent from which you will develop personal rules for your production that demonstrate a unique compositional structure, which is firm and identifiable.


Assessment involves research, proposal and execution of a major self-directed audiovisual work. This may include, but is not limited to, sound design, a short film, a built sound environment, field recording, image monograph or an architecturally projected video for example. Your work will be evaluated at three progress points throughout the session, at the end of which you will present your completed work accompanied by a written exegesis detailing your developmental processes with self-analysis of your outcomes. If you wish to innovate in an established genre you will need to clearly demonstrate how you intend to use critical analysis to challenge audience expectations or stylistic conventions in the creation of a new audio visual angle, approach, outcome or application. This course provides inspiration, creative experience and the opportunity to develop your studio practice in preparation for your Honours Project in your fourth year.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9a25cc58dbb1fc90be4672f5f396194f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Pitch","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

The pitch should address creative concepts, the project's viability, your engagement with the project and demonstrate a potential strategic purpose. You should lead with your creative concepts not the technique involved. The viability of the project will be measured by your project planning and ability to finalize the work by the end of session. Your engagement with the project will be measured by your depth of research and commitment. The strategic purpose of the project can be measured by your ambition: will the project ecology result in the final work being presented outside UNSW A&D, will the final work become part of a portfolio, will the research underlying your work evolve into a project that could be developed into an Honours project?

Your pitch should include:

  1. An illustration of your project concept.

  2. A short (5 min) presentation with potential research questions.

  3. The presentation format should be appropriate to illustrate your research. If relevant a very brief outline of previous work undertaken on this topic by others and how your work relates to that history.

  4. Include a speculative schedule for delivering the finished work by the end of session.

  5. Selected support materials from the field, such as creative influences, film-makers, artists, directors, animators or philosophers.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d625cc58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961951","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"de25cc58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"de25cc58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961951","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5a25cc58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961964","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Submission of major work","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Final delivery of creative work and written component.

Final submission of the major project involves a presentation of the completed work, accompanied by an appropriately referenced written exegesis which details the research relating to the artistic intent of the work, as outlined out in the lectures. This will be delivered by arrangement near the end of the session (leaving sufficient time for feedback). If there are special requirements such as an installation space or loud audio playback this needs to be arranged well before the due date.

In addition, a small summary statement of intent and design is required alongside the work as a card, talk, subtitle or other appropriate media. The work will be heard or seen by the class as a whole. If the work is a situational project or involves long periods of time it may be presented in the form of documentation, for example an audiovisual recording of a process.

Submit creative statement of intent and design in card, talk, subtitle or other appropriate media along with the creative work, referenced written final exegesis, any other relevant supporting documents and material.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d625cc58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d625cc58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961951","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"de25cc58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961951","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9625cc58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961953","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Work In Progress","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Work in progress – the creative work and writing about the creative work.

An interim presentation of the work in progress. You will need to critically describe your work to date, what has been achieved, what work is still required. The ongoing scheduling and employment of the time and facilities used to create the work. Identify the previous core concept and components from project pitch, are they in accord with the original pitch, have your concepts shifted, what improvement and action are required?  Identify how you have responded to feedback - how has the project changed after feedback? Identify a course of action for your future practice. If you are working collaboratively each team member should clearly describe their personal contribution.

Along with the creative work in progress submit a writing in progress that is in the form of a creative statement about the work. The lecturer will explain in detail the forms of writing required, creative statement / artistic statement, creative pitch and academic abstract which is a potential rehearsal for the Honors year.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d625cc58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d625cc58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961951","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"de25cc58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961951","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d225cc58dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961969","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/SOMA3415.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"SOMA3416","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOMA3416 - Imaging Effects Workshop","description":"

Imaging Effects Workshop draws together skills and learning in digital imaging, composition and motion graphics to introduce a coherent practice in visual effects. VFX involves the manufacture of an illusory reality by the artistic combination of elements drawn from the real world, which is then portrayed in print and on screen. The practice is an important part of current visual communication where the surreal is used to convey ideas and emotions alongside traditional moving image, photographic and animation techniques.


The course aims to develop a wider practice from skills that you have learned in earlier coursework. We start by firming your knowledge of digital imaging from still sources. We will then extend these techniques to moving elements and explore the added complexity this brings. Lastly we will move our compositions into three dimensions and gain experience with animation that tracks motion also drawn from the real world. Through these exercises you will develop skills that can assist your further explorations within photo media and moving image. Lectures will cover the history of visual effects across painting, photography, the pre-moving image and film. You will learn how meaning can be conveyed by manipulation of existing imagery.


The course is of use to all students in video, imaging, and animation, and particularly useful for those wishing to combine animated and real world imagery.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7e250098dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961917","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Animation Composite","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"In this exercise you are required to work in groups to combine animated media with video. Given the complexity of the task involved your sources will include some elements that have been prepared for this teaching task.The tutor is involved in pacing the stages of this process which will have weekly goals, aiming for completion in week 14. Working with a video source with proscribed elements (that provide sufficient data for the required task) you will place an animated element that 'tracks' the motions captured in the video and matches the overall quality of the video in terms of colour balance, light sources and so on. The result will be a video of no more than 30s in duration which you will present in class. Assessment is based on: - The use of camera and animated motion to convey an idea. - Skill and problem solving in creating a composition. - Creative use of provided assets.
The tutor will be involved closely in guiding each group's progress and will provide feedback as the task progresses. The intention is that any problems are picked up and discussed as they happen. Also the group is given running assessment of the quality of the work in progress. All the finished videos are screened for general discussion and feedback.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b2250098dbb1fc90be4672f5f396191a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ba250098dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961918","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ba250098dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961919","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"76250098dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961920","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Digital Image Composition (in two parts).","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"This project is assessed in two parts. In response to a brief set out in week one you will: - Consider an idea that responds to the brief. - Research previous work in image composition that is relevant to your own planning. Consider how this may influence your own production. - Propose a response to the brief by week 2, detailing how you will use digital composite skills to create an apparent reality that communicates the subject of the brief. - Explain the influence your work may take in perceptions of reality. You will then: - By week 5 present a digital still image that represents this apparent reality. - Describe how it was created in line with the proposal. The image should convey the concept as proposed by the use of digital darkroom, retouching, montage and other skills in digital compositing. You should be able to describe how the work is your own response to the reformation of reality.
The research and proposal should be made by week 2, to allow immediate feedback on whether the student has understood the requirements of the assessment task. It is a quick check that gives time to withdraw if the course is not as imagined. A 10% loading is only relevant in the context of the full task. It is expected that students have already completed one digital imaging course and so the turn around time from weeks 2 to 5 should be adequate to refresh their knowledge of digital composition, but this may need adjustment .","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b2250098dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b2250098dbb1fc90be4672f5f396191a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ba250098dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961918","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7a250098dbb1fc90be4672f5f396191b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Motion Image Composition","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"This exercise covers one common form of motion graphics which emulates the use of a rostrum camera. A virtual camera is moved over stills to create moving 'gaze' for the viewer. It is usually a '2D' effect - the camera tracks over flat planes and does not tilt. However some simple perspective effects can be used to add depth. The tutor will provide a new brief in week 5 after the still images are presented. You will be directed to start reading about motion graphics and approaches to the brief idea. You should: - Research previous work in motion graphics that is relevant to your own planning. Consider how this may influence your own production. - Propose a general response to the brief by week 6, outlining how you may use motion composite skills to communicate the subject of the brief. You will then: - By week 10 present a moving image piece that represents an apparent reality that communicates the idea required in the brief. The aim here is to provide more information than may be communicated by a still image. For example, to point out aspects of a photograph that may not otherwise be noticed. The student needs to not only provide the images but devise a meaningful pathway over their contents.The completed work will be a video of no more than 2 minutes duration that combines 'rostrum camera' and a sound recording that assists the images to convey their idea. The student may add any other component that improves the work, such as text. Assessment is based on: - The efficacy of the motion design in conveying the idea and in reinforcing a reality. - Experimentation and response to existing work in the format. - The overall design of image and sound as a coherent video work.
A proposal must be made in week 6, but given that motion graphics is a new skill, the expectation is that a general aspiration will be presented here - 'I would make something like this', 'I would like to try this idea'. This leads to a session where the tutor guides the students to techniques that relate to their ideas. The finished video works are screened by the class and a discussion is encouraged about how effective the results are in conveying the idea. The tutor leads a discussion comparing motion graphics to both photography and videography and the class develops a test for when each method is appropriate. There is also an opportunity to discuss why some movements seem real, and some seem artificial.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b2250098dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b2250098dbb1fc90be4672f5f396191a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ba250098dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961918","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"cf250098dbb1fc90be4672f5f3961924","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/SOMA3416.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description:
Imaging Effects Workshop draws together skills and learning in digital imaging, composition and motion graphics to introduce a coherent practice in visual effects. VFX involves the manufacture of an illusory reality by the artistic combination of elements drawn from the real world, which is then portrayed in print and on screen. The practice is an important part of current visual communication where the surreal is used to convey ideas and emotions alongside traditional moving image, photographic and animation techniques.

The course aims to develop a wider practice from skills that you have learned in earlier coursework. We start by firming your knowledge of digital imaging from still sources. We will then extend these techniques to moving elements and explore the added complexity this brings. Lastly we will move our compositions into three dimensions and gain experience with animation that tracks motion also drawn from the real world. Through these exercises you will develop skills that can assist your further explorations within photo media and moving image. Lectures will cover the history of visual effects across painting, photography, the pre-moving image and film. You will learn how meaning can be conveyed by manipulation of existing imagery.

The course is of use to all students in video, imaging, and animation, and particularly useful for those wishing to combine animated and real world imagery.

In this studio workshop the student is introduced to the basic concepts and future possibilities of digital imaging processes. The emphasis is on the integration of digital technologies into visual arts practices. The subject opens up for consideration a range of digital applications suitable for extending image production and visualisation. The student is introduced to the practice and methods of production of contemporary artists who utilise a variety of digital technologies in their work.

Final Cut Pro digital video editing software, simple DVD authoring and the processes of creating video installations are covered within the course. Classes include demonstrations, workshops, screenings, discussions and technical instruction.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOMA9755 - Motion Capture Studio","description":"

This course introduces you to motion capture technology (mocap) used to digitally capture the real time physical movements of people and objects for application in film, animation, visual effects, and games production; as well as experimentation in media and other creative disciplines relevant to your preferred area of career practice. 

You will gain theoretical and practical experience through a number of participatory exercises and practical assignments, including a project which requires you to apply data from a motion capture session to render an experimental animation sequence, digital animation character driven scene or similar creative outcome.

This course covers the professional workflow process, including the technical and aesthetic considerations involved in working with motion capture technology. You will be required to direct others in the capture of motion, as well as be directed by fellow students. You will be able to explore the interface to motion capture technology through both historical and contemporary outcomes. Emphasis will be placed on learning the steps needed to plan and run a successful shoot in a high-tech studio setting. You will take from this course the ability to use motion capture as a tool, coupled with an expanded knowledge of its use in industry relating to Media Arts, Film, Broadcast and Gaming. The course focuses on capturing human motion and moving props to provide you with initial training, which you can then apply later for producing work in areas like drawing, digital puppetry and facial motion capture.

The course provides proficiency for further independent or collaborative use of the motion capture facilities and equipment.

contentlets.description:
This course introduces you to motion capture technology (mocap) used to digitally capture the real time physical movements of people and objects for application in film, animation, visual effects, and games production; as well as experimentation in media and other creative disciplines relevant to your preferred area of career practice. 

You will gain theoretical and practical experience through a number of participatory exercises and practical assignments, including a project which requires you to apply data from a motion capture session to render an experimental animation sequence, digital animation character driven scene or similar creative outcome.

This course covers the professional workflow process, including the technical and aesthetic considerations involved in working with motion capture technology. You will be required to direct others in the capture of motion, as well as be directed by fellow students. You will be able to explore the interface to motion capture technology through both historical and contemporary outcomes. Emphasis will be placed on learning the steps needed to plan and run a successful shoot in a high-tech studio setting. You will take from this course the ability to use motion capture as a tool, coupled with an expanded knowledge of its use in industry relating to Media Arts, Film, Broadcast and Gaming. The course focuses on capturing human motion and moving props to provide you with initial training, which you can then apply later for producing work in areas like drawing, digital puppetry and facial motion capture.

The course provides proficiency for further independent or collaborative use of the motion capture facilities and equipment.
